Chapter 2
Naïve Set Theory

In the previous chapter we examined how to formulate, prove, and disprove statements. The example statements we looked at talked about numbers and squirrel, but the principles we examined apply regardless of which objects the statements talk about. In this chapter, we examine a class of objects that is so powerful that we can express everything from numbers to computers to proofs themselves in it. This class of objects will provide the foundation for everything we will study throughout this book.

Such a universal domain will allow us to apply very general concepts to arbitrarily specific situations. And yet you will find that the objects our statements will talk about are in themselves very simple. Striking that balance between simplicity and universality of foundational objects was arguably one of the key achievements of the 20th century: the development of set theory.

2.1: Sets

When attempting to define the foundations of mathematics, you run into a chicken-egg problem: Any definition needs to make use of mathematical concepts, so in particular the definition of the foundational objects also requires prior definitions. But then, it clearly is not foundational.

While there are sophisticated ways of avoiding this problem, they require a good understanding of mathematics to begin with. So we instead follow the traditional approach in teaching: our very first definition will be slightly informal, and we will simply pretend that it was sufficiently precise. Hence the “naïve” in the chapter title “naïve set theory”.

In particular, we will talk about mathematical “objects”, without specifically stating what those are. For our purposes, we require that an object is equal to itself but not to anything else. The number 17,17\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}17, for example, is a mathematical object.

Furthermore, every object must be “well-defined”, that is, it must always be clear which object we are talking about. For example, “the most important composer of the 18th century” is not well-defined; whether the most important composer of the 18th century is equal to Johann Sebastian Bach is a matter of personal opinion, not of mathematical reasoning.

In examples, we will use squirrel-related iconography11Attribution. for our mathematical objects: ,,,,\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}},,,, and .\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e900}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}. We know that =,≠,\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#eq}{=}} \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/neq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#neq}{\neq}} \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}=,=, and so on, and these are the only properties we ascribe to those symbols.

With that out of the way, it is time to look at the one definition upon which everything else in this book will build:

Definition 2.1: Set

A set is a collection of objects, characterized solely by which objects belong to it and which objects do not.

We denote a set by listing its objects within curly braces, separated by commas, for example: {,,}. \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}{,,}.

The empty set {} \left\lbrace \right\rbrace {} — the collection that contains no objects at all — is also written as ∅.\htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}∅.

Because a set is characterized by which objects belong to it, {,} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace {,} and {,} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \right\rbrace {,} are two different ways of denoting the same set. Informally speaking, sets ignore the order of their objects. Furthermore, {,,} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \right\rbrace {,,} and {,} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace {,} also denote the same set, you could say that sets ignore duplicates. All three expressions are simply different ways of denoting the unique mathematical object characterized by the fact that \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} and \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} belong to it, but nothing else does.

After the build-up about the foundational concept that is able to express anything you could possibly dream up, the notion of sets might initially be a bit of a letdown. We will get to the reasons for why sets are a very powerful concept soon enough, but first, we define and inspect some elementary terminology and notation.

Definition 2.2: Set Membership

To express that an object xxx occurs in a set X,X\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}X, we write x∈X,x \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}}} X\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈X, and we say that “xxx is an element of XXX”, “xxx is a member of XXX”, or simply that “xxx in XXX”.

If not x∈X,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} X\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈X, we write x∉X.x \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}}} X\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈/X.

Example 2.3
∈{,},\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}∈{,}, ∈{,},\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}∈{,}, and ∉{,}.\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}∈/{,}.

We can visualize set membership by drawing sets as blobs that enclose their elements. Example 2.4 demonstrates such an Euler diagram. Note how the idea of a set containing elements multiple times or in a particular order cannot even be expressed in these depictions22Once the universe of objects under consideration has been laid out., making Euler diagrams a more faithful representations of sets than our written notation.

Set Equality

Based on the notion of set membership, we can define precisely when two sets are considered equal.

Definition 2.5: Set Equality

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

We say AAA and BBB are equal, written as A=B,A \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A=B, if for each xxx holds that x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A if and only if x∈B.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈B.

If not A=B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A=B, we write A≠B.A \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=B.

Take a moment to consider some equivalent formulations for the “if and only if” in Definition 2.5:

  • A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B if every x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A is in BBB and every x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B is in A.A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A.
  • A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B if every x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A is in BBB and every x∉Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} Ax∈/A is not in B.B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}B.
  • A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B if every xxx is either in both AAA and BBB or in neither.

All of these ways of looking at set equality can come in handy when trying to prove that two complex descriptions of sets actually describe the same set. Example 2.6 visualizes the third interpretation.

Example 2.6: Set Equality

B≔{,}\htmlClass{cd3}{B} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \htmlClass{cd3}{\htmlClass{bgmclll3}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901} \right\rbrace }}B:={,}
A={,,}≠{,}=B\htmlClass{cd1}{A} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \htmlClass{cd1}{\htmlClass{bgmclll1}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{s3}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{s3}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e900}} \right\rbrace }} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} \htmlClass{cd3}{\htmlClass{bgmclll3}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{s3}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901}} \right\rbrace }} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \htmlClass{cd3}{B}A={,,}={,}=B

Two sets, with the elements that occur in exactly one of them highlighted in red. You can change the sets, note how the sets are equal exactly if no such highlighted elements remain.

Equipped with a precise definition of set equality, we can now prove some fundamental properties of equal sets.

Theorem 2.7: Reflexivity of =\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{=}=

Let AAA be a set. Then A=A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=A.

Proof of Theorem  2.7

Let AAA be a set, and let aaa be an object. We need to show that a∈Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Aa∈A if and only if a∈A.a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}a∈A.With the same proof structure, you can prove that any statement holds if and only it holds, which should not be particularly surprising. The proof of Theorem  2.7 might feel almost pointless if you look at things this way, but the definition of set equality dictates that this is how you have to prove the theorem.

“a∈A  ⟹  a∈Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Aa∈A⟹a∈A”:

If a∈A,a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}a∈A, then a∈Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Aa∈A by assumption.

“a∉A  ⟹  a∉Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} Aa∈/A⟹a∈/A”:

If a∉A,a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}a∈/A, then a∉Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} Aa∈/A by assumption.

Thus, by the definition of set equality, we have that A=A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=A.

Theorem 2.8: Symmetry of =\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{=}=

Let AAA and BBB be sets. If A=B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A=B, then B=A.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}B=A.

Theorem 2.9: Transitivity of =\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{=}=

Let A,A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A, B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, and CCC be sets. These properties might feel so self-evidently true (just picture the Euler diagrams) that it can initially be hard to know where to even begin proving them. But the overall approach when establishing properties for freshly defined concepts is always the same: you unfold the definition of the concept until you are only working with older concepts, you use their known properties to prove what you need, and finally you translate it back into the new terminology.

Exercise 2.1

Let A,A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A, B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, and CCC be sets. Prove or disprove: if A≠BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} BA=B and B≠C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B=C, then A≠C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=C.

We disprove the statement by giving a counterexample. Define A≔{},A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A:={}, B≔{},B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B:={}, and C≔{}.C \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}C:={}. Then A≠BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} BA=B (because ∈A\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A∈A but ∉B\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} B∈/B), B≠CB \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} CB=C (because ∈B\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B∈B but ∉C\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} C∈/C), but A=C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=C.

The definition of set equality also justifies why we talk about “the empty set” and not “an empty set”. The set of numbers that are both less than 12 and greater than 17, and the set of unicorns grazing on the Eiffel Tower33None as of writing. are precisely the same mathematical object.

Subsets

We can think of set equality as a very strict way of looking for similarity between two sets. But there are more general ways in which two sets can be related. It might be the case, for example, that one set contains all elements of another set, but not necessarily the other way around. This relation is common enough that we give it a name:

Definition 2.10: Subset, Superset

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

We say AAA is a subset of B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, written as A⊆B,A \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A⊆B, if for each x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A holds x∈B.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈B.

Conversely, we say that BBB is a superset of A,A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A, written as B⊇A,B \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B⊇A, if A⊆B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A⊆B.

We further write A⊈BA \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}}} BA⊈B if not A⊆B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A⊆B, and A⊉BA \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsupseteq}}} BA⊉B if not A⊇B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A⊇B.

Explore Example 2.11 for a bit. What do you expect to happen when both sets are equal? What should happen when one of them is empty?

A≔{,,}\htmlClass{cd1}{A} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \htmlClass{cd1}{\htmlClass{bgmclll1}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e900} \right\rbrace }}A:={,,}

Two sets and the subset and superset relations between them.

If you compare the definitions of set equality and subsets, you can see that the definition of subsets is essentially one direction of the bi-implication in the definition of set equality. In other words, two sets are equal if they are both subsets and supersets of each other. Formally:

Observation 2.12
Let AAA and BBB be sets. Then A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B if and only if A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA⊆B and A⊇B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A⊇B.
Proof of Observation  2.12
Proofs are hidden in this book when either it makes for a good exercise to try to prove the statement yourself, or when they are uninteresting enough to only be included for the sake of completeness. Which option it is, depends on you and how well you grasp the material already. When in doubt, use them as an opportunity to improve your skills.

This alternate characterization offers yet another way of proving set equality; you can show that two sets are equal by showing that they are mutual subsets.

If you played around a bit with Example 2.11, you may have noticed that the empty set is a subset of every set. To understand why, we need to take a close look at how subsets are defined. The definition talks about “all x∈A”,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{”,}}x∈A”, so what happens if A=∅?A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{?}}A=∅? There exists no xxx such that x∈∅,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈∅, so what does that mean for the definition?

On an intuitive level, you can say that in order to show that some set is a subset of another, you need to show that a certain property holds for each of its members. As the empty set has no members, you do not need to show anything.

More formally, the phrase “for each x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A holds bla” is a shorthand for the phrase “for each object xxx holds that x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A implies bla”. With that knowledge, we can formally prove that the empty set is a subset of every set:

Theorem 2.13

Let AAA be a set. Then ∅⊆A.\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}∅⊆A.

Proof of Theorem  2.13

Let xxx be an object. We need to show that x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ implies x∈A,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈A, so assume that x∈∅.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈∅.

Because the empty set has no members, we know that x∉∅.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈/∅. As we cannot have x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ and x∉∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈/∅ simultaneously (by the principle of bivalence), x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A holds by the principle of explosion.

Whenever a statement of universal quantification holds because it is constrained to elements from the empty set, we say that the statement holds vacuously.

Exercise 2.2

Based on your knowledge about negating universal quantifications, give a full picture of how statements like “there exists x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ such that bla” work out.

Such a statement is always false; intuitively speaking, it is impossible to find a witness that is in the empty set.

“There exists x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ such that bla” is equivalent to its double negation “it does not hold that there exists no x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ such that bla”. This in turn is equivalent to “it does not hold that for each x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ not bla”, which is the negation of a vacuously true statement, and thus false.

The concept of subsets is ubiquitous in mathematics, so use the following exercises and theorems to familiarize yourself with it. They also present a good opportunity to practice your deductive reasoning skills.

Exercise 2.3

Give sets A,A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A, B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, and C,C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}C, such that A⊆CA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} CA⊆C and B⊆C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B⊆C, but A⊈BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}} BA⊈B and B⊈A.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}B⊈A.

Define A≔{},A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A:={}, B≔{},B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B:={}, and C≔{,}.C \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}C:={,}. Then A⊆CA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} CA⊆C and B⊆C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B⊆C, but A⊈BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}} BA⊈B (because ∈A\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A∈A but ∉B)\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{)}}∈/B) and B⊈AB \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}} AB⊈A (because ∈B\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B∈B but ∉A).\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{).}}∈/A).

Theorem 2.14: Reflexivity of ⊆\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\subseteq}⊆

Let AAA be a set. Then A⊆A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A⊆A.

Strict Subsets

Subsets express that some set contains at least every member of another set. Sometimes we want to express that a set also contains at least one further object:

Definition 2.16: Strict Subset, Strict Superset

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

We say AAA is a strict subset of B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, written as A⊂B,A \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A⊂B, if A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA⊆B and A≠B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=B.

Conversely, we say AAA is a strict superset of B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, written as A⊃B,A \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\supset}}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A⊃B, if A⊇BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} BA⊇B and A≠B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=B.

We further write A⊄BA \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\not\subset}}} BA⊂B if not A⊂B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A⊂B, and A⊅BA \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\not\supset}}} BA⊃B if not A⊃B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\supset}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A⊃B.

Being a strict subset is a stronger notion than being a subset, that is, every strict subset of some set is also a regular subset of that set:

Observation 2.17

Let AAA and BBB be sets. If A⊂B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A⊂B, then A⊆B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A⊆B.

Proof of Observation  2.17

Let AAA and BBB be sets. Then

A⊂B  ⟹  A⊆B and A≠B  ⟹  A⊆B\begin{align*}A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} B &\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} \text{$A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B$ and $A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B$} \tag{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\htmlClass{ref definition}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html, width=}{Definition}}} $\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\subset}$}\\ &\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B \tag{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#conjunction}{\htmlClass{ref definition}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/conjunction.html}{Conjunction}}}}\end{align*}A⊂B​⟹A⊆B and A=B⟹A⊆B​(Definition ⊂)(Conjunction)​

Strict subsets behave similar to (possibly non-strict) subsets, but the following exercises also highlight some differences.

Theorem 2.18: Transitivity of ⊂\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\subset}⊂

Let A,A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A, B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, and CCC be sets. If A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B and B⊂C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B⊂C, then A⊂C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A⊂C.

Proof of Theorem  2.18

Let A,A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A, B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, and CCC be sets. Assume that A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B and B⊂C.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}B⊂C.

By Observation  2.17 we have that A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA⊆B and B⊆C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B⊆C, and by the transitivity of ⊆\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\subseteq}⊆ we have that A⊆C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A⊆C. It remains to show that A≠C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=C.

Since A≠BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} BA=B but every member of AAA is a member of BBB (both hold because A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B), there exists some x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B with x∉A.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈/A. Because x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B and B⊂C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B⊂C, we know that x∈Cx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Cx∈C. And as x∉A,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈/A, we get that A≠C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=C.

Exercise 2.5

Let AAA and BBB be sets. Prove or disprove: if A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B and B⊂A,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B⊂A, then A=B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=B.

This has no consequences for the validity of the proof however, because any implication with a false premise holds regardless.

Exercise 2.6

The statement does not hold, so we prove its negation. Because A⊂B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A⊂B, there exists x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B such that x∉A.\htmlClass{bgclll6 highlight low}{x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈/A. Then x∈C,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈C, because x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B and B⊂C.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}B⊂C. But then also x∈A,\htmlClass{bgclll6 highlight low}{x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈A, because x∈Cx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Cx∈C and C⊂A,C \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}C⊂A, a contradiction.

2.2: Combining Sets

When considering multiple sets, some objects might be in exactly one of them, while others might be in multiple of them. Take, for example, the three sets of animal species that can walk, swim, or fly respectively. We might be interested in the set of all species that can walk and swim but cannot fly. In this section, we introduce terminology for deriving such sets from other sets.

Figure 2.19 visualizes the example in a Venn diagram, a special type of Euler diagram that shows all possible ways in which some sets can overlap.

Figure 2.19

A Venn diagram showing the sets of animal species that can walk, fly, and swim. Each of the seven resulting regions shows an icon44Attribution. of a species that belongs to it.

So far, we have always denoted sets by explicitly enumerating their members, which does not help us when trying to define a set in terms of other sets. For that reason, we introduce the set builder notation, in which we specify a set by giving a predicate that is satisfied exactly by the members of that set (read the vertical bar (“∣\mid∣”) as “such that”):

{x∣x∈{,,} and x∈{,,}},\big \lbrace x \mid \text{$x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \right\rbrace $ and $x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901} \right\rbrace $} \big \rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}{x∣x∈{,,} and x∈{,,}}, for example, is a complicated way of denoting the set {,}. \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}{,}.

As this notation is more of a technicality than an interesting new concept, we shall not dwell on it any further.

Intersection and Union

We now define our terminology for the objects that occur in both of two sets:

Definition 2.20: Intersection

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

The intersection of AAA and B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, written as A∩B,A \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A∩B, is the set of all objects which are elements of both AAA and B:B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{:}}B: A∩B≔{x∣x∈A and x∈B}.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left \lbrace x \mid \text{$x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A$ and $x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B$} \right \rbrace .A∩B:={x∣x∈A and x∈B}.

If we swap the conjunction in the definition of the intersection of two sets for a disjunction, we obtain another useful concept:

Definition 2.22: Union

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

The union of AAA and B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, written as A∪B,A \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A∪B, is the set of all objects which are elements of at least one of AAA or B:B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{:}}B: A∪B≔{x∣x∈A or x∈B}.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left \lbrace x \mid \text{$x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A$ or $x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B$} \right \rbrace .A∪B:={x∣x∈A or x∈B}.

Intersection and union are binary operators, that is, they combine exactly two sets. If we wish to combine more than two sets, we group the sets as pairs in parentheses and can then compute those pairs successively:

Exercise 2.7

Compute

Grouping nested intersections and unions with parentheses is necessary in general, because there are expressions for which the exact grouping makes a difference in the result:

Statement 2.24

Theorem 2.25: Associativity of ∩\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\cap}∩

If the way in which we group multiple occurrences of a binary operator has no influence on the result, we call that operator associative. To keep our notation clean from unnecessary details, we allowed to omit grouping parentheses for associative operators. It is fine, for example, to write “A∪B∪C”.\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{“}}\nobreak A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} C\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{”.}}“A∪B∪C”. For all binary operators that have not been proven associative, we always provide the parentheses to indicate the exact grouping.

Intersection and union inherit the associativity of conjunctions and disjunctions respectively fairly directly. Using structurally similar proofs, we can show that they inherit their commutativity as well:

Two further simple but useful observations are that intersections never add elements, and unions never remove elements:

The following exercises present further opportunities to become more familiar with intersections and unions, as well as to practice proving statements in general.

Exercise 2.8

Let AAA and BBB be sets. Show that A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA⊆B if and only if A∩B=A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A∩B=A.

Proof of Theorem  2.31

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

  1. “A∩(A∪B)⊆AA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} AA∩(A∪B)⊆A”

    Holds by Theorem  2.29.

    “A∩(A∪B)⊇AA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} AA∩(A∪B)⊇A”

    Let xxx be an object. If x∈A,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈A, then also A∪B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A∪B, and then also x∈A∩(A∪B).x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B \right) \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈A∩(A∪B).

  2. “A∪(A∩B)⊆AA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} AA∪(A∩B)⊆A”

    We show the contraposition, that is, we show that if an object is not in A,A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A, then it is not in A∪(A∩B)A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \right) A∪(A∩B) either. To that end, let xxx be an object. If x∉A,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈/A, then also x∉A∩B,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈/A∩B, and then also x∉A∪(A∩B).x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \right) \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈/A∪(A∩B).

    “A∪(A∩B)⊇AA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} AA∪(A∩B)⊇A”

    Holds by Theorem  2.30.

Exercise 2.10

Theorem  2.31 is annotated with a series of Venn diagrams which demonstrate that the equation in question holds. Other, similar statements include such visualizations as well (Theorem  2.25, Theorem  2.26, not displayed in the tooltips). A diagram is clearly not a (written) proof, the actual proofs do not directly relate to the diagrams, and yet these visualizations unescapably convey the equality of the two sides of the equation.

  1. How can the information contained in such a diagram be mechanically translated into a proof of equality?
  2. Give a written proof of Theorem  2.31 that corresponds directly to the visualization.
  3. How do you feel about these proofs compared to more natural proofs like those given in the book?

  1. Every region of a Venn diagram corresponds to one particular way in which the membership of some object with respect to all involved sets can work out. The diagram as a whole lists all possible ways in which any object can relate to the sets (the easily forgotten outer region corresponds to objects which are not members of any depicted set).

    So overall, we can translate a diagram into a written proof by taking some object xxx, and then doing a case distinction over membership in all sets in question. In each individual case, the information about set membership suffices to compute whether the object is in further intersections or unions. Thus we can show that in each case the object is either in both or none of the sets on either side of the equation.

  2. Let AAA and BBB be sets, and let xxx be an object. We show that x∈A∩(A∪B)x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B \right) x∈A∩(A∪B) if and only if x∈A.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈A.

    If x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A and x∈B,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈B, then x∈A∪B,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈A∪B, and then x∈A∩(A∪B).x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B \right) \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}x∈A∩(A∪B). As also x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A by assumption, we have x∈A∩(A∪B)x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B \right) x∈A∩(A∪B) if and only if x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A in this case.

    As the claim holds in every case, it holds in general.

    For the sake of brevity, we omit the corresponding proof of A∪(A∩B)=AA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} AA∪(A∩B)=A.

  3. The resulting proofs are rather long and uninspired compared to more natural proofs. They may be correct, but they convey little information about the structure of the problem at hand. Then again, even an uninspired proof is better than no proof at all. So do not be afraid to start slinging those case distinctions when you cannot make progress with a proof.

    Even though the written form of these diagrams can feel clunky, many people find the diagrams themselves quite elegant. This is a remarkable testament to our ability to process visual information much more naturally than symbolic information. Many mathematicians think about problems in imagery, with the translation into written language as an almost incidental last step. Care must be taken however that the visualization is indeed an accurate representation of the problem; checking whether the visual information can be mechanically translated into a complete account of the situation in written language is a good habit to have.

Set Difference

Intersection and union are arguably the two most simple operations on sets, but sometimes they do not suffice. Consider, for example, the set of animal species that can swim but cannot fly. We cannot construct this set using intersection and union only. We thus define a third binary operator:

Definition 2.32: Set Difference

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

The set difference of AAA and B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, relative complement of BBB in A,A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A, or simply AAA without B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, written as A∖B,A \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A∖B, is the set of all objects which are elements of AAA but not of B:B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{:}}B: A∖B≔{x∣x∈A and x∉B}.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left \lbrace x \mid \text{$x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A$ and $x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} B$} \right \rbrace .A∖B:={x∣x∈A and x∈/B}.

An immediate observation we can make about the set difference operation is that removing elements from a set always results in a (not necessarily strict) subset:

Theorem 2.34

Let AAA and BBB be sets. Then A∖B⊆A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A∖B⊆A.

Proof of Theorem  2.34

Let AAA and BBB be sets, and let xxx be an object. If x∈A∖B,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}x∈A∖B, then also x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A by definition of ∖,\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}}\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}∖, and thus A∖B⊆A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A∖B⊆A.

Unlike intersection and union, set difference is sensitive to both the order of the two sets to be combined, and the grouping of multiple set differences.

When computing intersections by hand, a helpful technique is to write down one of the sets and to then cross out the elements that do not occur in the other set. An example: {,,,}∩{,,}={,,,}={,}. \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e900} \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901} \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{cancel_symbol}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{cancel_symbol}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e900}} \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901} \right\rbrace .{,,,}∩{,,}={,,,}={,}. We can prove that this technique always yields the correct result — take a moment to think through how the following theorem relates to the technique:

Theorem 2.37

Let AAA and BBB be sets. Then A∩B=A∖(A∖B).A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} \big( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \big) \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A∩B=A∖(A∖B).

Proof of Theorem  2.37

Let AAA and BBB be sets, and let xxx be an object.

“A∩B⊆A∖(A∖B)A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} \big( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \big) A∩B⊆A∖(A∖B)”:

2.3: Sets of Sets

With a solid understanding of the basic predicates (membership, equality, and being a (strict) subset) and operators (intersection, union, and set difference) of set theory under our belt, we can now examine what makes sets so powerful.

A set can contain arbitrary mathematical objects. A set is a mathematical object itself. See where this is going? Sets can contain other sets!

We can have nested sets such as {{,},{,},} \Big\lbrace \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace , \allowbreak \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \right\rbrace , \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901} \Big\rbrace {{,},{,},}, and our predicates work just as before: {,}∈{{,},{,},}, and{{,},}⊆{{,},{,},}.\begin{align*}\htmlClass{bgmclll1}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \right\rbrace } &\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \Big\lbrace \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace , \allowbreak\htmlClass{bgmclll1}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \right\rbrace }, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901} \Big\rbrace \text{, and}\\ \Big\lbrace \htmlClass{bgmclll3}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace }, \allowbreak\htmlClass{bgmcllldirect5}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901}} \Big\rbrace &\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} \Big\lbrace \htmlClass{bgmclll3}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace }, \allowbreak \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \right\rbrace , \allowbreak\htmlClass{bgmcllldirect5}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901}} \Big\rbrace .\end{align*}{,}{{,},}​∈{{,},{,},}, and⊆{{,},{,},}.​

Always stay mindful of the difference between the members of a set and the members of its members: ∉{{,},{,},},\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} \Big\lbrace \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace , \allowbreak \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \right\rbrace , \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901} \Big\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}∈/{{,},{,},}, even though \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904} is an element of some members of {{,},{,},}. \Big\lbrace \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903} \right\rbrace , \allowbreak \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} \right\rbrace , \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901} \Big\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}{{,},{,},}.

Another common source of mistakes is the distinction between an object and the set that contains exactly that object but nothing else. For each set XXX holds {X}≠X, \left\lbrace X \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} X\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}{X}=X, because X∈{X}X \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \left\lbrace X \right\rbrace X∈{X} but X∉XX \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} XX∈/X, as no set can be a member of itself. In particular, ∅≠{∅}.\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} \left\lbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}∅={∅}. The empty set has no members, whereas {∅} \left\lbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right\rbrace {∅} has exactly one member, namely the empty set.

Because we can nest sets arbitrarily deeply, we can represent even the most complex mathematical concepts through sets. Sometimes we do so explicitly by defining the concepts in terms of sets, sometimes we will simply assume implicitly that it would be possible to express concepts in terms of sets. We have been using icons such as ,\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e904}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e903},, and \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e902} as objects, for example, but since their only interesting property is how they behave in terms of equality, we might as well have been using the sets ∅,{∅},\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}, \left\lbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}∅,{∅}, and {{∅}} \left\lbrace \left\lbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right\rbrace \right\rbrace {{∅}} instead. Using symbols is more readable, but ultimately not necessary from a purely mathematical standpoint66Expressing everything in terms of pure sets is indeed how more formal approaches to set theory eliminate the problem of having to define objects before being able to define sets..

Power Sets

One particular kind of set of sets that we will encounter repeatedly throughout this book arises from the following question: Given some set XXX, which sets are there that contain no objects but those from XXX (although not necessarily all of them)? This is in fact the same as asking for the set of subsets of XXX — take a moment to think through why that is. It is this viewpoint we use for our proper definition:

Definition 2.38: Power Set

Let XXX be a set.

The power set of X,X\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}X, written as P⁡(X),\htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( \htmlClass{text_color}{X} \right) }\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}P(X), is the set of all subsets of X.X\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}X.

Example 2.39: Power Set
A≔{,}A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e900} \right\rbrace A:={,}
P⁡(A)={∅,{},{},{,},}\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( A \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \big\{\\ \hspace{2em} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}, \\ \hspace{2em} \htmlClass{powerset7}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901} \right\rbrace }, \htmlClass{powerset15}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e900} \right\rbrace }, \\ \hspace{2em} \htmlClass{powerset23}{ \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e901}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\char"e900} \right\rbrace }, \\ \big\}P(A)={∅,{},{},{,},}
A visualization of the power set construction. The empty set is a member of every power set, even though the Euler diagram never depicts it.

Notice how “A⊆UA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} UA⊆U” and “A∈P⁡(U)A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( U \right) A∈P(U)” mean the same thing.

The definition of power sets is very short, yet the power set of the empty set initially feels unintuitive to many learners. Think through the following two exercises however, and you should be fine.

Exercise 2.17

Find the mistake in the following claim: because the empty set is a subset of every set (Theorem  2.13) and every set is a subset of itself (Theorem  2.14), P⁡(X)\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( X \right) P(X) must contain at least two elements for each set X.X\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}X.

The argument ignores that the empty set and the set itself could be one and the same. And indeed, P⁡(∅)={∅},\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \left\lbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right\rbrace \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}P(∅)={∅}, a set which only contains a single element.
