Power sets have a number of interesting properties, but for now it shall suffice to note that power sets are unique to each set77A very different statement from the trivial observation that every set has exactly one power set.:

Theorem 2.40

Let AAA and BBB be sets. If P⁡(A)=P⁡(B),\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( A \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( B \right) \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}P(A)=P(B), then A=B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=B.

Proof of Theorem  2.40

We do a proof by contraposition, that is, we show that if A≠B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A=B, then P⁡(A)≠P⁡(B).\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( A \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( B \right) \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}P(A)=P(B). To that end, let AAA and BBB be sets with A≠B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A=B.

Without loss of generality, there exists a∈Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Aa∈A such that a∉Ba \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} Ba∈/B (otherwise switch the roles of AAA and BBB). Then {a}∈P⁡(A) \left\lbrace a \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( A \right) {a}∈P(A) (because {a}⊆A)\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{}}\nobreak \left\lbrace a \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{)}}{a}⊆A) but {a}∉P⁡(B) \left\lbrace a \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( B \right) {a}∈/P(B) (because {a}⊈B),\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{}}\nobreak \left\lbrace a \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{),}}{a}⊈B), and thus, P⁡(A)≠P⁡(B).\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( A \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( B \right) \nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}P(A)=P(B).

The proof of Theorem  2.40 contains the handy phrase “without loss of generality”, which indicates that only one of several distinct cases will be presented, because the other cases work in a similar way and can be handled through simple modifications to the presented argument. In this example, it is clearly not always true that AAA has a member that is not in B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, as AAA could be a (strict) subset of B.B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}B. But in that case, simply renaming AAA to “BBB” and vice versa correctly finishes the proof.

Quickly jotting down a “without loss of generality” (or “w.l.o.g.” for the particularly time-pressed mathematician) can often lead to overlooking crucial corner cases, resulting in faulty proofs. Whenever you feel tempted to wlog88It may not have been a verb before, but now it is. your way out of a lengthy proof, ask yourself whether you can describe the necessary changes to cover all cases in one sentence. If you can, then simply add that sentence to your proof. And if you cannot, then you do not get to drop those convenient four words.

2.4: Conclusion

This concludes our first foray into set theory. Almost all of modern mathematics99Alternate formalisms that can serve as foundations of mathematics include category theory and type theories. Set theory however is by far the most widely used one, both in teaching and in actual research. builds upon the notion of sets, with its predicates of membership, equality, and subsets, and the operations of intersection, union, set difference, and power set.

By now, you should have developed a solid intuitive understanding of these predicates and operations. You should also be able to work with their formal definitions and prove statements that relate them to each other.

The proofs in this chapter rarely required a brilliant idea, but rather demonstrated the basic workflow of breaking down definitions and letting the structure of the statements in question guide the proof. This alone will get you quite far, a significant part of mathematics is solid, unexciting craftsmanship. It might not be glamorous, but it yields good results.

Throughout the examples and exercises of this chapter, all specific sets contained finitely many elements. The definition of sets does not require this, it is perfectly fine for a set to contain infinitely many objects. All our proofs work perfectly fine for infinite sets. Infinite sets come with their own challenges however, starting with the simple question of how to even define an infinitely large object through a finite mathematic expression. The answers to that and several other problems are what we will cover in the next chapter.

2.5: Exercises

This section contains a collection of exercises that touch upon all definitions of this chapter. Some introduce new but related definitions, so make sure to read through the exercises even if you do not intend to solve all of them. Unlike the exercises throughout the chapter body, these exercises do not come with solutions. Write your own instead, and try to get feedback on them.

Definition 2.43: Symmetric Difference

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

The symmetric difference of AAA and B,B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}B, written as A△⁡B,A \htmlClass{define_notation}{\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/symmetric_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#symmetric_difference}{\operatorname{\triangle}}}} B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{,}}A△B, is the set of all objects which are elements of exactly one of AAA or B:B\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{:}}B: A△⁡B≔(A∖B)∪(B∖A).A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/symmetric_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#symmetric_difference}{\operatorname{\triangle}}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} \left( B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} A \right) .A△B:=(A∖B)∪(B∖A).

Theorem 2.44: Commutativity of △⁡\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/symmetric_difference.html}{\operatorname{\triangle}}△

Let AAA and BBB be sets. Then A△⁡B=B△⁡A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/symmetric_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#symmetric_difference}{\operatorname{\triangle}}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/symmetric_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#symmetric_difference}{\operatorname{\triangle}}} A\nobreak\htmlClass{normal_text}{\text{.}}A△B=B△A.
